docs.title: Compleasy Documentation
docs.text:
Welcome to the Compleasy documentation!

Compleasy is a Linux server auditing solution based on Lynis. It is designed to simplify and automate the process of ensuring your servers adhere to security and operational policies.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Easy implementation: Compleasy server is a Docker-based solution that can be deployed in minutes
  • Easy configuration: Compleasy client is based on Lynis, which can be installed on any Linux server in seconds
  • Centralized management: All audit results are sent to the Compleasy server, where they can be viewed and managed
  • Customizable policies: Compleasy allows you to define custom policies that can be applied to all servers

docs.title: Upload Report
docs.text:
Upload a Lynis audit report.

Endpoint: POST /api/lynis/upload/

Legacy: POST /api/v1/lynis/upload/

Request Format: Form data

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description licensekey string Yes License key for authentication hostid string Yes Host identifier hostid2 string No Secondary host identifier data string Yes Base64-encoded Lynis report data

Response:

  • 200 OK - Report uploaded successfully
  • 400 Bad Request - Invalid request data
  • 401 Unauthorized - Invalid license key

Example:

curl -X POST https://yourserver:3000/api/lynis/upload/ \
  -F "licensekey=your-license-key" \
  -F "hostid=server-01" \
  -F "data=$(base64 -w 0 /var/log/lynis-report.dat)"

docs.title: Check License
docs.text:
Validate a license key.

Endpoint: POST /api/lynis/license/

Legacy: POST /api/v1/lynis/license/

Request Format: Form data

Parameters:

Parameter Type Required Description licensekey string Yes License key to validate collector_version string No Lynis collector version

Response:

  • 200 OK - Valid license (Response: Response 100)
  • 401 Unauthorized - Invalid license (Response: Response 500)

Example:

curl -X POST https://yourserver:3000/api/lynis/license/ \
  -F "licensekey=your-license-key" \
  -F "collector_version=3.0.0"

Lynis Compatibility

These endpoints maintain compatibility with Lynis clients. The response format (Response 100 / Response 500) is required for Lynis compatibility.

docs.title: API Examples
docs.text: Code examples and integration patterns for Compleasy API.

docs.title: Upload Report
docs.text:
import requests
import base64

# Read Lynis report
with open('/var/log/lynis-report.dat', 'rb') as f:
    report_data = base64.b64encode(f.read()).decode('utf-8')

# Upload to Compleasy
response = requests.post(
    'https://yourserver:3000/api/lynis/upload/',
    data={
        'licensekey': 'your-license-key',
        'hostid': 'server-01',
        'data': report_data
    },
    verify=False  # For self-signed certificates
)

if response.status_code == 200:
    print('Report uploaded successfully')
else:
    print(f'Error: {response.text}')

docs.title: Get Devices
docs.text:
import requests

# Using session authentication
session = requests.Session()
session.post(
    'https://yourserver:3000/login/',
    data={'username': 'admin', 'password': 'password'}
)

response = session.get('https://yourserver:3000/api/devices/')
devices = response.json()

for device in devices['devices']:
    print(f"Device: {device['hostid']}, Compliance: {device['compliance']}%")

docs.title: Upload Report Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

LICENSE_KEY="your-license-key"
SERVER="https://yourserver:3000"
HOSTID=$(hostname)

# Read and encode report
REPORT_DATA=$(base64 -w 0 /var/log/lynis-report.dat)

# Upload report
curl -k -X POST "${SERVER}/api/lynis/upload/" \
  -F "licensekey=${LICENSE_KEY}" \
  -F "hostid=${HOSTID}" \
  -F "data=${REPORT_DATA}"

if [ $? -eq 0 ]; then
    echo "Report uploaded successfully"
else
    echo "Failed to upload report"
    exit 1
fi

docs.title: Check License Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash

LICENSE_KEY="your-license-key"
SERVER="https://yourserver:3000"

RESPONSE=$(curl -k -s -X POST "${SERVER}/api/lynis/license/" \
  -F "licensekey=${LICENSE_KEY}")

if [ "$RESPONSE" = "Response 100" ]; then
    echo "License is valid"
    exit 0
else
    echo "License is invalid"
    exit 1
fi

docs.title: Custom Lynis Profile
docs.text:
Add to /etc/lynis/custom.prf:

upload=yes
license-key=your-license-key
upload-server=yourserver:3000/api/lynis
upload-options=--insecure

docs.title: Automated Upload
docs.text:
Add to cron:

# Run audit and upload daily at 2 AM
0 2 * * * /usr/sbin/lynis audit system --upload --quick

docs.title: Python Error Handling
docs.text:
import requests
from requests.exceptions import RequestException

try:
    response = requests.post(
        'https://yourserver:3000/api/lynis/upload/',
        data={'licensekey': 'key', 'hostid': 'host', 'data': '...'},
        timeout=30,
        verify=False
    )
    response.raise_for_status()
except RequestException as e:
    print(f'Request failed: {e}')
except Exception as e:
    print(f'Unexpected error: {e}')

docs.title: SECRET_KEY
docs.text:
Django secret key for cryptographic signing.

SECRET_KEY=your-secret-key-here

Security Critical

NEVER commit your actual secret key to version control. Generate a new unique key for each deployment.

Generate a secure key: 

python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_urlsafe(50))"

docs.title: DJANGO_DEBUG
docs.text:
Enable or disable Django debug mode.

DJANGO_DEBUG=False  # Production (default)
DJANGO_DEBUG=True   # Development only

Never Enable in Production

Setting DJANGO_DEBUG=True in production exposes sensitive information including stack traces, environment variables, and database queries.

docs.title: DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS
docs.text:
Comma-separated list of allowed hostnames.

DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=yourdomain.com,www.yourdomain.com

For development, you can use: 

DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=*

Production Security

Never use * in production. Always specify exact hostnames.

docs.title: DJANGO_ENV
docs.text:
Environment type selector.

DJANGO_ENV=development   # Development settings (default)
DJANGO_ENV=production    # Production settings
DJANGO_ENV=testing       # Testing settings

docs.title: Security Configuration
docs.text: Security best practices and hardening guide for Compleasy.

docs.title: Production Security Checklist
docs.text:
• DJANGO_DEBUG=False is set
  • DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS is configured (not *)
  • SECRET_KEY is unique and secure
  • Default admin password is changed
  • HTTPS is enabled with security headers
  • Rate limiting is enabled
  • PostgreSQL is used (not SQLite)
  • Regular backups are configured

docs.title: Debug Mode
docs.text:
Critical

NEVER enable debug mode in production.

DJANGO_DEBUG=False

Debug mode exposes: - Stack traces with code - Environment variables - Database queries - Internal file paths

docs.title: Allowed Hosts
docs.text:
Always specify exact hostnames:

DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=yourdomain.com,www.yourdomain.com

Never use: 

DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=*  # INSECURE

docs.title: Secret Key
docs.text:
Generate a unique, secure secret key for each deployment:

python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_urlsafe(50))"

Never reuse secret keys across deployments.

docs.title: Enable HTTPS Redirect
docs.text: SECURE_SSL_REDIRECT=True

docs.title: HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS)
docs.text:
SECURE_HSTS_SECONDS=31536000  # 1 year
SECURE_HSTS_INCLUDE_SUBDOMAINS=True
SECURE_HSTS_PRELOAD=True

docs.title: Secure Cookies
docs.text:
SESSION_COOKIE_SECURE=True
CSRF_COOKIE_SECURE=True

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text:
Enable rate limiting to protect against abuse:

RATELIMIT_ENABLE=True

Rate limits apply to: - API endpoints (/api/lynis/upload/, /api/lynis/license/) - Login attempts - Registration attempts

docs.title: Use PostgreSQL in Production
docs.text:
SQLite is fine for development, but PostgreSQL provides: - Better concurrency - Connection pooling - Better security features

See PostgreSQL Setup for details.

docs.title: Database Credentials
docs.text:
• Use strong passwords
  • Limit database user permissions
  • Use connection encryption
  • Regularly rotate credentials

docs.title: Change Default Credentials
docs.text:
Never use default admin credentials in production:

COMPLEASY_ADMIN_USERNAME=admin
COMPLEASY_ADMIN_PASSWORD=your-strong-password-here

docs.title: Password Requirements
docs.text: Ensure strong passwords: - Minimum 12 characters - Mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols - Not dictionary words - Not reused from other services

docs.title: Firewall Configuration
docs.text: Only expose necessary ports: - 3000 (or your configured port) for HTTP/HTTPS - Database port only to application server (if external)

docs.title: Reverse Proxy
docs.text: Use a reverse proxy (Nginx, Apache) for: - SSL/TLS termination - Additional security headers - Rate limiting - DDoS protection

docs.title: Security Headers
docs.text:
Compleasy includes security headers, but you can add more via reverse proxy:

X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
X-Frame-Options: DENY
X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'self'

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This section covers installing and setting up Compleasy.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Compleasy consists of two main components:

  1. Compleasy Server - The central server that receives and manages audit reports
  2. Lynis Client - The auditing tool installed on each server you want to monitor

docs.title: Installation Options
docs.text:
• Docker Installation - Recommended for most users (quick setup)
  • PostgreSQL Setup - Database configuration for production
  • Client Setup - Configuring Lynis clients to send reports

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before installing Compleasy, ensure you have:

  • Docker and Docker Compose installed
  • A secure SECRET_KEY generated for Django
  • (Optional) PostgreSQL for production deployments

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After installation, proceed to:

  • Configuration - Configure environment variables and security settings
  • Getting Started - Learn how to use Compleasy

docs.title: Client Setup
docs.text: This guide explains how to configure Lynis clients to send audit reports to your Compleasy server.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A running Compleasy server
  • A license key (generated by the server)
  • Lynis installed on the client server

docs.title: 1. Install Lynis
docs.text:
On Debian/Ubuntu:

sudo apt install lynis

On other distributions, use your package manager or install from source.

docs.title: 2. Generate License Key
docs.text:
First, you need to obtain a license key from your Compleasy server. This can be done through:

  • The web interface (after logging in)
  • The admin API endpoint
  • The management command

docs.title: 3. Create Custom Profile
docs.text:
Create a custom Lynis profile at /etc/lynis/custom.prf:

# Custom profile for Compleasy
upload=yes
# License key from Compleasy server
license-key=YOUR_LICENSE_KEY
# Point to the Compleasy server
upload-server=yourserver:3000/api/lynis
# Required for self-signed certificates
upload-options=--insecure

# Custom settings
# Too slow. Old systems do not support ignoring some directories
test_skip_always=CRYP-7902

Replace: - YOUR_LICENSE_KEY with your actual license key - yourserver:3000 with your Compleasy server address

docs.title: 4. Run Audit
docs.text:
Run Lynis with the custom profile:

lynis audit system --upload --quick

This will: 1. Perform a system audit 2. Upload the results to your Compleasy server

Upload Only

You can use lynis only-upload to upload the last audit results without running a new audit.

docs.title: 5. Schedule Regular Audits
docs.text:
For automated monitoring, schedule regular audits with cron.

On recent Debian/Ubuntu versions, you can use the systemd timer:

systemctl start lynis.timer
systemctl enable lynis.timer

Or create a cron job:

# Edit crontab
crontab -e

# Add line to run audit daily at 2 AM
0 2 * * * /usr/sbin/lynis audit system --upload --quick

docs.title: Recommended Packages
docs.text:
For the most comprehensive audit results, install these packages:

sudo apt install rkhunter auditd aide

These packages enable additional security checks: - rkhunter: Rootkit detection - auditd: Linux audit daemon - aide: File integrity monitoring

docs.title: Connection Issues
docs.text:
If you're having trouble connecting to the server:

  1. Check server URL: Ensure upload-server points to the correct address
  2. Check firewall: Ensure port 3000 (or your configured port) is open
  3. Check SSL: If using HTTPS, ensure certificates are valid or use --insecure flag

docs.title: License Key Issues
docs.text:
If you get license key errors:

  1. Verify the license key is correct in /etc/lynis/custom.prf
  2. Check that the license key exists in Compleasy server
  3. Ensure the license key hasn't been revoked

docs.title: Upload Failures
docs.text:
If uploads fail:

  1. Check network connectivity: curl -k https://yourserver:3000/api/lynis/license
  2. Check server logs: docker compose logs compleasy
  3. Verify the API endpoint is accessible

docs.title: 1. Copy the Example Environment File

docs.text: python3 -c "import secrets; print(secrets.token_urlsafe(50))"

For development environments only, you can enable DEBUG mode:

Security Warning

NEVER set DJANGO_DEBUG=True in production environments. Running with DEBUG enabled exposes sensitive information including stack traces, environment variables, and database queries to potential attackers.

For production, set allowed hosts:

DJANGO_ALLOWED_HOSTS=yourdomain.com,www.yourdomain.com

docs.title: 1. Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/compleasy/compleasy.git
cd compleasy

docs.title: 2. Start Compleasy
docs.text:
docker compose up

This will:

  • Build the Compleasy Docker image
  • Start the web server
  • Initialize the database
  • Create default admin user

docs.title: 3. Access Compleasy
docs.text:
Once started, access Compleasy at:

http://localhost:3000

Default credentials: - Username: admin - Password: compleasy

Change Default Password

Never use default admin credentials in production. Set COMPLEASY_ADMIN_PASSWORD in your .env file.

Before deploying to production, collect static files:

docker compose -f docker-compose.yml run --rm compleasy python manage.py collectstatic --no-input

SECURE_SSL_REDIRECT=True
SECURE_HSTS_SECONDS=31536000
SESSION_COOKIE_SECURE=True

docs.title: PostgreSQL Setup
docs.text: Compleasy uses SQLite by default for easy installation, but PostgreSQL is strongly recommended for production deployments.

docs.title: Why PostgreSQL?
docs.text:
• Better Performance: Handles concurrent connections and large datasets more efficiently
  • Concurrency: SQLite has limitations with concurrent writes
  • Reliability: Better transaction handling and data integrity
  • Scalability: Better suited for production workloads

docs.title: Quick Setup with Docker Compose
docs.text: The easiest way to set up PostgreSQL is using Docker Compose.

docs.title: 1. Add PostgreSQL Service
docs.text:
Add a PostgreSQL service to your docker-compose.yml:

services:
  postgres:
    image: postgres:15-alpine
    environment:
      POSTGRES_DB: compleasy
      POSTGRES_USER: compleasy_user
      POSTGRES_PASSWORD: your_secure_password_here
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    healthcheck:
      test: ["CMD-SHELL", "pg_isready -U compleasy_user"]
      interval: 10s
      timeout: 5s
      retries: 5

volumes:
  postgres_data:

docs.title: 2. Configure DATABASE_URL
docs.text:
Set the DATABASE_URL environment variable in your Compleasy service:

services:
  compleasy:
    environment:
      DATABASE_URL: postgresql://compleasy_user:your_secure_password_here@postgres:5432/compleasy

Or add it to your .env file:

DATABASE_URL=postgresql://compleasy_user:your_secure_password_here@postgres:5432/compleasy

docs.title: 3. Run Migrations
docs.text: docker compose exec compleasy python manage.py migrate

docs.title: 1. Install PostgreSQL
docs.text:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install postgresql postgresql-contrib

# macOS (with Homebrew)
brew install postgresql
brew services start postgresql

docs.title: 2. Create Database and User
docs.text:
# Connect to PostgreSQL
sudo -u postgres psql

# Create database and user
CREATE DATABASE compleasy;
CREATE USER compleasy_user WITH PASSWORD 'your_secure_password_here';
ALTER ROLE compleasy_user SET client_encoding TO 'utf8';
ALTER ROLE compleasy_user SET default_transaction_isolation TO 'read committed';
ALTER ROLE compleasy_user SET timezone TO 'UTC';
GRANT ALL PRIVILEGES ON DATABASE compleasy TO compleasy_user;
\q

docs.title: 3. Set DATABASE_URL
docs.text:
export DATABASE_URL=postgresql://compleasy_user:your_secure_password_here@localhost:5432/compleasy

Or add it to your .env file.

docs.title: Verifying Connection
docs.text:
After setting up PostgreSQL, verify the connection:

# Check if Compleasy can connect
docker compose exec compleasy python manage.py dbshell

# Or test the connection
docker compose exec compleasy python manage.py shell

from django.db import connection
connection.ensure_connection()
print("PostgreSQL connection successful!")

docs.title: Migration from SQLite
docs.text:
If you're already running with SQLite and want to migrate to PostgreSQL:

  1. Backup your SQLite database: 

    docker compose exec compleasy python manage.py dumpdata > backup.json

  2. Set up PostgreSQL (as described above)

  3. Load data into PostgreSQL: 

    docker compose exec compleasy python manage.py loaddata backup.json

SQLite for Development

SQLite is perfectly fine for small deployments, testing, or development. PostgreSQL becomes important when you have multiple concurrent users, large amounts of data, or need high availability.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Policies in Compleasy allow you to:

  • Define security and operational requirements
  • Apply rules to devices
  • Track compliance against policies
  • Get recommendations for improvement

docs.title: Policy Rules
docs.text:
Individual rules that define specific requirements:

  • Test ID - Lynis test identifier
  • Operator - Comparison operator (equals, greater than, etc.)
  • Value - Expected or threshold value
  • Severity - Warning or error level

docs.title: Policy Rule Sets
docs.text:
Collections of rules that can be applied to devices:

  • Name - Descriptive name for the rule set
  • Description - Purpose and scope
  • Rules - List of policy rules

docs.title: 1. Create a Policy Rule
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Policies → Rules
  2. Click Create New Rule
  3. Configure:
  4. Test ID (e.g., FILE-7524)
  5. Operator (equals, not equals, greater than, etc.)
  6. Expected value
  7. Severity level
  8. Save the rule

docs.title: 2. Create a Policy Rule Set
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Policies → Rule Sets
  2. Click Create New Rule Set
  3. Enter name and description
  4. Select rules to include
  5. Save the rule set

docs.title: 3. Apply to Devices
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Devices
  2. Select a device
  3. Go to Policy Rulesets
  4. Assign rule sets to the device

docs.title: File Permissions
docs.text:
Ensure critical files have correct permissions:

  • Test ID: FILE-7524
  • Operator: equals
  • Value: 640
  • Severity: Warning

docs.title: SSH Configuration
docs.text:
Require SSH key authentication:

  • Test ID: SSH-7408
  • Operator: equals
  • Value: yes
  • Severity: Error

docs.title: System Updates
docs.text:
Ensure system is up to date:

  • Test ID: PKGS-7390
  • Operator: less than
  • Value: 7 (days since last update)
  • Severity: Warning

docs.title: Viewing Compliance
docs.text:
1. Navigate to a device
  2. Click Compliance
  3. See compliance status for each rule
  4. Review failed rules and recommendations

docs.title: Compliance Reports
docs.text:
• Overall compliance percentage
  • Per-rule compliance status
  • Historical compliance trends
  • Recommendations for improvement

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Start Simple - Begin with a few critical rules
  • Test First - Test policies on non-production devices
  • Document - Document why each rule is important
  • Review Regularly - Review and update policies regularly
  • Organize - Group related rules into rule sets

docs.title: Report Analysis
docs.text: Learn how to view and analyze audit reports in Compleasy.

docs.title: Device Reports
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Devices
  2. Click on a device
  3. View the latest report and compliance status

docs.title: Report Details
docs.text:
Each report includes:

  • Audit Date - When the audit was performed
  • Compliance Status - Overall compliance percentage
  • Warnings - Security warnings found
  • Suggestions - Recommendations for improvement
  • Test Results - Individual test results

docs.title: Compliance Status
docs.text: Overall compliance percentage based on: - Applied policy rules - Test results - Severity levels

docs.title: Warnings
docs.text: Security warnings that need attention: - High Priority - Critical security issues - Medium Priority - Important recommendations - Low Priority - Best practice suggestions

docs.title: Suggestions
docs.text: Actionable recommendations: - Configuration changes - Package installations - System hardening steps

docs.title: Compare Reports
docs.text: Compare reports over time to: - Track compliance trends - Identify regressions - Measure improvement

docs.title: Filter and Search
docs.text:
• Filter by test category
  • Search for specific tests
  • Focus on failed tests

docs.title: Export Reports
docs.text: Export reports for: - Documentation - Compliance audits - Sharing with teams

docs.title: Test Categories
docs.text:
Lynis organizes tests into categories:

  • Authentication - Login and access controls
  • Boot Services - System startup services
  • File Systems - File permissions and security
  • Firewall - Network security
  • Kernel - System kernel settings
  • Networking - Network configuration
  • Processes - Running processes
  • Storage - Disk and storage security

docs.title: Test Severity
docs.text:
• Error - Critical issues requiring immediate attention
  • Warning - Important recommendations
  • Suggestion - Best practice improvements

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Review Regularly - Check reports after each audit
  • Address Warnings - Prioritize high-severity warnings
  • Track Trends - Monitor compliance over time
  • Document Actions - Document remediation steps
  • Share Findings - Share reports with relevant teams

docs.text:
